body:
### Problem

I hit this on Githubs CI, where I was setting `NVIM_APPNAME=$some_uuid` and generating long paths, not sure how applicable this is to "real world" use.

Windows paths are capped at 260 chars. The loader generates a rfc2396 encoded string of a module path, and puts that under the cache dir, so `c:\mod\file.lua` is stored at `c:\users\the-user\appdata\local\temp\<appname>\luac\c%3a%3fmod%3ffile.luac`.

If `mod\file.lua` is nested somewhere deep (say where a package manager might install it) and has some nesting of its own, and the user name is long, and/or the app_name is long, the encoded luac path can fail to write, and then the module fails to load, even if the module is loadable without the loader enabled.

There are ways to extend the path limit [here](https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/windows/win32/fileio/maximum-file-path-limitation?tabs=registry), unsure if Neovim uses an application manifest though, and it requires a user registry edit.

In 0.9 the paths are just encoded as `%`, instead of `%FF`, so its possible this could be an unpleasant experience for some when upgrading in the future.

### Steps to reproduce

```powershell
# powershell -ExecutionPolicy Bypass x.ps1

$env:NVIM_APPNAME = [Guid]::NewGuid().ToString()

# create file in appname dir, with a long path
$appDataDir = [System.Environment]::GetFolderPath([System.Environment+SpecialFolder]::LocalApplicationData)
$luaDir = "$appDataDir\$env:NVIM_APPNAME\lua"

$long = "aaa\aaa\aaa\aaa\aaa\aaa\aaa\aaa\aaa\aaa\aaa\aaa\aaa\aaa\a\a"
$modname = $long.Replace("\", ".")
mkdir "$luaDir\$long"
$luaFile = "$luaDir\$long.lua"
Set-Content -Path $luaFile -Value "print(1)"
echo $appDataDir
echo $luaFile

# install nvim 0.10 via msi package
& 'c:\Program Files\Neovim\bin\nvim' -v
# works, raw path is under limits
& 'c:\Program Files\Neovim\bin\nvim' $luaFile +":lua=require('$modname')"
# fails, luac path is too long.
# uses rfc2396 encoding, where \ becomes %f2 (1 char becomes 3)
& 'c:\Program Files\Neovim\bin\nvim' $luaFile +":lua vim.loader.enable()" +":lua=require('$modname')"

# install nvim 0.9 via choco
# uses plain \ to % encoding (1 char becomes 1)
nvim $luaFile +":lua=require('$modname')"
nvim $luaFile +":lua vim.loader.enable()" +":lua=require('$modname')"


```

### Expected behavior

The module loads, or maybe a nicer warning is given telling the user to swap OS or disable the loader for long paths automatically?

### Neovim version (nvim -v)

NVIM v0.10.0-dev-1025+g0e11bf0e1

### Vim (not Nvim) behaves the same?

NA

### Operating system/version

Windows 11

### Terminal name/version

Windows Terminal

### $TERM environment variable

NA?

### Installation

"latest" release msi package for

comment_data.body: One workaround is to simply disable the cache for this scenario.

title: `vim.loader` luac file paths can end up too long for windows to load
